1.14.text:
“You look like a freak.”
“What planet did you come from?”

4.23.text:
“You’re going to regret that.”
“Who would find that attractive?”

15.05.text:
“You look like a freak”
Freak look good.

18.37.text:
I have it tattooed here.
I love being a freak.

20.36.text:
And she was like, “Why do you look like
a freak? You’re scaring my kid.” And I’m

23.67.text:
like, “You’re kid is sleeping…”
The amount of kids I see that go, “Mummy

27.19.text:
she’s got blue hair!” And it’s always
the mums that go, “Don’t, don’t look.”

30.87.text:
What do you think I’m going to do?
Kids love us because we’re colourful, we’ve

35.56.text:
got blingy stuff.
Kids love us yeah.

36.69.text:
If you’re going to try and insult me at
least get my genre right. It’s mermaid goth,

39.96.text:
in case you’re wondering.
I will fly that flag for the freaks out there.

48.37.text:
“You must love pain”
I do, kind of. I guess, a little bit.

53.40.text:
No, I’m a pansy.
I love pain, on my morning toast.

57.47.text:
It depends, skin removal I fucking love.
Neck tattoos hurt worse than childbirth.

62.67.text:
I had my tongue split, I had my elbows tattooed,
I had my ears stretched, you know, I had plastic

67.57.text:
surgeries, I had like so much, I got suspended
on hook and stuff. Epilation; the worst.

73.14.text:
Yeah you know how people like, take the same
selfie every day and it’s like, I find that

76.85.text:
painful. Is that not like pain?
Oh, “Do you worship the devil?”

83.85.text:
Like, people think you look different so you
must be satanic.

87.04.text:
We are gluten free vegans, so we don’t do
satan.

90.01.text:
We don’t do satan, no.
And they will give you like, verses of the

93.89.text:
bible. Everything, everything is justified.
Oh my God I know.

96.86.text:
People just automatically assume you’re
a criminal, or you’re a bad person, or you’re

100.40.text:
going to just, hurt them.
My household is not satan’s den. My household

106.02.text:
smells like incense, and herbal tea.
Is this my turn?

113.10.text:
“What happens when you go through airport
security?”

115.44.text:
I just, you know, catwalk. You just go fabulous.
People have asked me that so many times and

121.51.text:
the same with magnets as well.
I mean I don’t have any implants so. And

125.94.text:
when I have my big earrings I just remove
them and that’s it.

129.34.text:
Once yeah, when I had my nipples pierced it
was like, “beep beep beep.” And it was

134.03.text:
like. And he was like, “Piercings?” And
I was like, “Just don’t go any lower…”

142.68.text:
Me!
I don’t know I get quite a lot of, “Hmm

147.44.text:
sexy” comments.
But don’t forget, you are married.

150.73.text:
Oh yeah.
People with body mods usually have got a certain

155.25.text:
profile. They’re usually independent, they
usually know what they want and basically,

161.40.text:
they’re brave enough to just be who they
are.

163.81.text:
When I got my tongue split, or any scarification
or anything, I feel like I’m becoming more

168.17.text:
of me.
There’s nothing wrong with it, at least

170.70.text:
just being yourself.
I don’t think you should just settle for

173.37.text:
what you were given.
Why would anyone split their tongue?

176.41.text:
That’s so horrible.
You have yours done! I’m so jealous.

182.41.text:
Yeah, I’m against it. I worry for the children.
“Isn’t that a bit extreme?”

192.78.text:
Yes, it is extreme.
What is extreme? This is my normality.

199.16.text:
This is what I love about having a child.
Like, to some people, this is extreme. But

204.57.text:
to us, and to her, this is so normal.
It’s part of my culture. My mum has scarification.

210.58.text:
Body modification isn’t a new thing. In
fact, it’s incredibly old.

214.88.text:
You can get your ears pierced to having your
butt done. And that’s all acceptable. But

219.02.text:
this is not.
It’s like people that have the elf ears

221.98.text:
or the split tongue or something. It just
feels like something you should have.

225.15.text:
So I chopped off my finger because I think
it looks cute. Who cares?

228.40.text:
As long as you don’t harm anyone else and
you do it for your own, for yourself.

233.20.text:
I think it’s a beautiful thing to bring
a child into, because they just see people

237.17.text:
for who they are.
“What about your wedding photos?”

250.49.text:
Single. What wedding?
I dressed in whatever I felt comfortable in.

255.40.text:
And you were quite heavily pregnant.
Yeah.

257.53.text:
I mean, on my wedding day I had a skin fade.
Me and my husband had matching haircuts.

263.57.text:
If I ever get married, I’ve always said
that I’m going to have like, a Halloween

266.01.text:
themed wedding.
It may not be the white dress, it may be something

269.64.text:
else. It’s going to be how we want it to
be, it’s going to look like me.

273.85.text:
“Why can’t you just be like everyone else?”
Imagine if everyone looked like the same in

281.58.text:
life.
It’s like, watching ‘Star Wars: Attack

283.51.text:
of the Clones’ just…
I’ve never watched it.

285.72.text:
I get told that I shouldn’t look this way,
I shouldn’t have coloured hair, I’ve ruined

290.57.text:
myself.
People expect you to think a certain way,

294.83.text:
to look a certain way.
No, I’ve made myself so much happier by

298.54.text:
looking weirder, and looking different.
I just wish more people could really feel

304.32.text:
themselves properly and be, and create, whoever
they want to be.

309.67.text:
What is it?
You want to wear the foot?

312.39.text:
I am myself, because everybody else is already
taken.

316.55.text:
Is it pretty? Is it a mermaid?
No you’re cookie.
